benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/customFields/search - Search custom fields by type, name and optional value

covered: Valid Request: multiple happy-path searches and combinations are covered (TC01–TC06, TC37).
Empty Response: cases for no-matches and empty DB are present (TC11, TC28).
Pagination: basic pagination, large-limit and out-of-range offset behaviors are tested (TC07, TC21, TC22).
Query Parameters: many combinations of objectType/fieldName/fieldValue and unexpected params are covered; invalid parameter values are also tested (TC02–TC06, TC12–TC16, TC19, TC20).
Audit handling & dependent service behavior: audit levels and integration/degradation/unavailability are covered (TC08–TC10, TC18, TC32, TC33).
Security validation: SQL injection and XSS attempts are explicitly tested (TC19, TC20).
Performance / Load / Concurrency: response-time and heavy-load scenarios and concurrent requests are included (TC23, TC24, TC30, TC31).
Accessibility / Error messaging: documentation and descriptive errors are checked (TC34, TC35).
Regression & backward compatibility: regression checks and legacy-client behavior are present (TC25–TC27).
gaps: Rate Limiting: no tests covering API throttling/rate-limit responses (e.g., 429) or behavior under rapid repeated requests.
Caching Behavior / Conditional GETs: no scenarios validate Cache-Control, ETag, Last-Modified, or If-None-Match / 304 responses.
Authorization scopes / Forbidden responses: tests only cover missing auth (401) but not forbidden scenarios (403) or role/scope-based access restrictions.
Header & Content Negotiation: no tests for Accept/Content-Type handling or enforcement of application/json response headers.
Default & boundary semantics: absence of explicit tests asserting default limit/offset values and behavior when limit exceeds configured maximum (e.g., default=100, max-limit enforcement).
Combined edge-cases: no explicit tests combining audit=FULL with pagination and timeouts to verify consistent behavior when both features are used together.
Rate-limiting vs concurrency: concurrency test exists but does not assert the system reacts correctly when limits are exceeded (backoff, 429).

Schema enforcement across scenarios: while some scenarios mention schema conformance, there is no explicit, consistent schema-validation test for all successful responses (e.g., every TC that returns 200 should validate the CustomField schema and audit sub-schema).
Negative / malformed headers and types: no tests for malformed query parameter types beyond numeric negatives (e.g., non-integer offset/limit format errors, overly long strings).
recommendations: Add explicit rate-limiting tests: simulate burst traffic and verify responses include 429 or documented behavior and appropriate Retry-After headers.
Add caching / conditional-get tests: assert Cache-Control and ETag are present where expected; test If-None-Match / 304 behavior and consistent ETag changes after resource updates.
Add forbidden/scope tests: create scenarios where authenticated users lack required role/permission and assert 403 responses and descriptive error payloads.
Add header/content-negotiation tests: verify Accept header handling and that responses are application/json with correct charset; test malformed/missing Accept handling.
Add boundary/default tests for pagination: assert default limit (100) is applied when limit omitted, test max-limit enforcement and behavior when limit > max configured value.
Add combined-feature edge tests: audit=FULL with pagination/large result sets/timeouts to validate consistent behavior and error handling when dependent services are slow or time out.
Introduce consistent schema validation steps in all successful scenarios: automated JSON schema assertions for CustomField objects and audit blocks (FULL/MINIMAL/NONE).

Add tests for malformed types and extreme input lengths: non-integer offset/limit (e.g., offset=abc), extremely long fieldName/fieldValue, and ensure validation errors are returned without side effects.
